byline.original: By J. DAVID GOODMAN and MATT FLEGENHEIMER

abstract: New York City Police Dept pilot program encourages performers who dance on subway trains for tips to move above ground and confine their activities to spaces set aside for them; program has led to decline in arrests of dancers, which had more than doubled in 2014; effort is part of Mayor Bill de Blasio's attempts to maintain broken-windows policing while easing burden on those disproportionately affected by it.
lead_paragraph: After arrests for performers more than doubled last year, the de Blasio administration is setting aside outdoor space as part of a pilot program to curb illicit performances on the train.

headline.main: Instead of Arrests, Subway Dancers Are Getting a Stage Above Ground
